note.p: Birth: Essex Street, Strand, London, England (12 March 1790)
Death: At the Royal Society, whilst attending a meeting of the Council, London (13 March 1845)

Career: Invented the hygrometer which was named after him (1820); made meteorological observations; invented a water barometer and a pyrometer (1832); Professor of Chemistry, King's College London (1831); invented the constant battery which was named after him and which won him the Copley Medal
Medals/Prizes: Rumford Medal 1832; Copley Medal 1837; Royal Medal 1842
Obituaries: Proc Roy Soc 1845 No 62 pp 577-580
References: David A Cumming, 'John MacCulloch, FRS, at Addiscombe: The Lectureships in Chemistry and Geology' in NR 1979-80 vol 34 pp 155-183
V Gold, 'Samuel Taylor Coleridge and the Appointment of J F Daniell, FRS, as Professor of Chemistry at King's College London' in NR 1973-4 vol 28 pp 25-29
W H Brock, 'William Prout and Barometry' in NR 1969 vol 24 pp 281-294
S Ross, 'Faraday Consults the Scholars: the Origins of the Terms of Electrochemistry' in NR 1961 vol 16 pp 187-220
